title: 114_hr275
content: SECTION 1. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The sense of Congress is that intercollegiate athletic programs benefit student athletes and campus life, but recent events threaten the financial stability of athletic programs. There are concerns about the health and safety of student athletes and academic integrity at institutions of higher education. Academic integrity in higher education is at risk due to academic fraud among student athletes, lack of support for academically unprepared athletes, and excessive time demands for athletics. Student athletes facing loss of benefits and NCAA institutions at risk of penalties lack adequate due process. The NCAA and college leaders have not effectively addressed these issues, necessitating reform by a commission of sports experts. A blue ribbon commission of sport experts and members of Congress should be convened to objectively study academic integrity issues in higher education related to student athletes and propose solutions. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics is established to address academic integrity issues in higher education related to student athletes and propose solutions. The Commission will review issues related to intercollegiate athletics, including the interaction of athletics and academics, graduation rates of student athletes, academic eligibility standards, and financing sources like student fees and media contracts. The Commission will review financial aspects of intercollegiate athletics, including revenue expenditures, financing ability, transparency, criteria for rewards, and rules on earnings and benefits for student athletes. The Commission will also address recruitment, retention, oversight, governance practices, and health/safety protections for student athletes. The Commission will develop recommendations on issues such as health and safety protections for student athletes, due process in enforcing rules, and other relevant matters in intercollegiate athletics. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, and majority leader of the Senate. Members include individuals from Congress and those who are not members. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders in Congress. Appointments are based on qualifications and vacancies are filled in the same manner. The Chair is elected by the members, who serve without pay. Members of the Commission serve without pay but are entitled to reimbursement for travel and other necessary expenses incurred while carrying out their functions. The Commission may appoint staff without following standard government hiring procedures, with a limit on pay. Meetings will be called by the Chair or majority members, with the first meeting within 90 days. The Commission has powers outlined in the Act. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and access information from government agencies to carry out the Act. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission can request administrative support services on a reimbursable basis to fulfill its responsibilities under the Act. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics established by section 2 must submit a report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. The Act defines the Commission and "institution of higher education."
